trans-unit.source: Variable assets in Azure Automation | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Variable assets in Azure Automation | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Variable assets are values that are available to all runbooks in Azure Automation. This article explains the details of variables and how to work with them in both textual and graphical authoring.
trans-unit.target: Variable assets are values that are available to all runbooks in Azure Automation. This article explains the details of variables and how to work with them in both textual and graphical authoring.

trans-unit.source: Variable assets are values that are available to all runbooks in your automation account.
trans-unit.target: Variable assets are values that are available to all runbooks in your automation account.

trans-unit.source: They can be created, modified, and retrieved from the Azure portal, Windows PowerShell, and from within a runbook.
trans-unit.target: They can be created, modified, and retrieved from the Azure portal, Windows PowerShell, and from within a runbook.

trans-unit.source: Automation variables are useful for the following scenarios:
trans-unit.target: Automation variables are useful for the following scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Share a value between multiple runbooks.
trans-unit.target: Share a value between multiple runbooks.

trans-unit.source: Share a value between multiple jobs from the same runbook.
trans-unit.target: Share a value between multiple jobs from the same runbook.

trans-unit.source: Manage a value from the portal or from the Windows PowerShell command line that is used by runbooks.
trans-unit.target: Manage a value from the portal or from the Windows PowerShell command line that is used by runbooks.

trans-unit.source: Automation variables are persisted so that they continue to be available even if the runbook fails.
trans-unit.target: Automation variables are persisted so that they continue to be available even if the runbook fails.

trans-unit.source: This also allows a value to be set by one runbook that is then used by another, or is used by the same runbook the next time that it is run.
trans-unit.target: This also allows a value to be set by one runbook that is then used by another, or is used by the same runbook the next time that it is run.

trans-unit.source: When a variable is created, you can specify that it be stored encrypted.
trans-unit.target: When a variable is created, you can specify that it be stored encrypted.

trans-unit.source: When a variable is encrypted, it is stored securely in Azure Automation, and its value cannot be retrieved from the <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet that ships as part of the Azure PowerShell module.
trans-unit.target: When a variable is encrypted, it is stored securely in Azure Automation, and its value cannot be retrieved from the <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet that ships as part of the Azure PowerShell module.

trans-unit.source: The only way that an encrypted value can be retrieved is from the Get-AutomationVariable activity in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: The only way that an encrypted value can be retrieved is from the Get-AutomationVariable activity in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: Secure assets in Azure Automation include credentials, certificates, connections, and encrypted variables.
trans-unit.target: Secure assets in Azure Automation include credentials, certificates, connections, and encrypted variables.

trans-unit.source: These assets are encrypted and stored in the Azure Automation using a unique key that is generated for each automation account.
trans-unit.target: These assets are encrypted and stored in the Azure Automation using a unique key that is generated for each automation account.

trans-unit.source: This key is encrypted by a master certificate and stored in Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: This key is encrypted by a master certificate and stored in Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: Before storing a secure asset, the key for the automation account is decrypted using the master certificate and then used to encrypt the asset.
trans-unit.target: Before storing a secure asset, the key for the automation account is decrypted using the master certificate and then used to encrypt the asset.

trans-unit.source: When you create a variable with the Azure portal, you must specify a data type from the dropdown list so the portal can display the appropriate control for entering the variable value.
trans-unit.target: When you create a variable with the Azure portal, you must specify a data type from the dropdown list so the portal can display the appropriate control for entering the variable value.

trans-unit.source: The variable is not restricted to this data type, but you must set the variable using Windows PowerShell if you want to specify a value of a different type.
trans-unit.target: The variable is not restricted to this data type, but you must set the variable using Windows PowerShell if you want to specify a value of a different type.

trans-unit.source: If you specify Not defined, then the value of the variable will be set to $null, and you must set the value with the Set-AzureAutomationVariable cmdlet or Set-AutomationVariable activity.
trans-unit.target: If you specify Not defined, then the value of the variable will be set to $null, and you must set the value with the Set-AzureAutomationVariable cmdlet or Set-AutomationVariable activity.

trans-unit.source: You cannot create or change the value for a complex variable type in the portal, but you can provide a value of any type using Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You cannot create or change the value for a complex variable type in the portal, but you can provide a value of any type using Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Complex types will be returned as a <linkText>PSCustomObject</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Complex types will be returned as a <linkText>PSCustomObject</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can store multiple values to a single variable by creating an array or hashtable and saving it to the variable.
trans-unit.target: You can store multiple values to a single variable by creating an array or hashtable and saving it to the variable.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlets in the following table are used to create and manage Automation variables with Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlets in the following table are used to create and manage Automation variables with Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: They ship as part of the <linkText>Azure PowerShell module</linkText><title></title> which is available for use in Automation runbooks.
trans-unit.target: They ship as part of the <linkText>Azure PowerShell module</linkText><title></title> which is available for use in Automation runbooks.

trans-unit.source: Cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Cmdlets

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Retrieves the value of an existing variable.
trans-unit.target: Retrieves the value of an existing variable.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Creates a new variable and sets its value.
trans-unit.target: Creates a new variable and sets its value.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Remove-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Remove-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Removes an existing variable.
trans-unit.target: Removes an existing variable.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Sets the value for an existing variable.
trans-unit.target: Sets the value for an existing variable.

trans-unit.source: The workflow activities in the following table are used to access Automation variables in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: The workflow activities in the following table are used to access Automation variables in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: They are only available for use in a runbook and do not ship as part of the Azure PowerShell module.
trans-unit.target: They are only available for use in a runbook and do not ship as part of the Azure PowerShell module.

trans-unit.source: Workflow Activities
trans-unit.target: Workflow Activities

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Get-AutomationVariable
trans-unit.target: Get-AutomationVariable

trans-unit.source: Retrieves the value of an existing variable.
trans-unit.target: Retrieves the value of an existing variable.

trans-unit.source: Set-AutomationVariable
trans-unit.target: Set-AutomationVariable

trans-unit.source: Sets the value for an existing variable.
trans-unit.target: Sets the value for an existing variable.

trans-unit.source: You should avoid using variables in the –Name parameter of Get-AutomationVariable in a runbook since this can complicate discovering dependencies between runbooks and Automation variables at design time.
trans-unit.target: You should avoid using variables in the –Name parameter of Get-AutomationVariable in a runbook since this can complicate discovering dependencies between runbooks and Automation variables at design time.

trans-unit.source: From your automation account, click Assets at the top of the window.
trans-unit.target: From your automation account, click Assets at the top of the window.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the window, click Add Setting.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the window, click Add Setting.

trans-unit.source: Click Add Variable.
trans-unit.target: Click Add Variable.

trans-unit.source: Complete the wizard and click the checkbox to save the new variable.
trans-unit.target: Complete the wizard and click the checkbox to save the new variable.

trans-unit.source: From your automation account, click the Assets part to open the Assets blade.
trans-unit.target: From your automation account, click the Assets part to open the Assets blade.

trans-unit.source: Click the Variables part to open the Variables blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Variables part to open the Variables blade.

trans-unit.source: Click Add a variable at the top of the blade.
trans-unit.target: Click Add a variable at the top of the blade.

trans-unit.source: Complete the form and click Create to save the new variable.
trans-unit.target: Complete the form and click Create to save the new variable.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>New-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet creates a new variable and sets its initial value.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>New-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet creates a new variable and sets its initial value.

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve the value using <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve the value using <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If the value is a simple type, then that same type is returned.
trans-unit.target: If the value is a simple type, then that same type is returned.

trans-unit.source: If it’s a complex type, then a PSCustomObject is returned.
trans-unit.target: If it’s a complex type, then a PSCustomObject is returned.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands show how to create a variable of type string and then return its value.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands show how to create a variable of type string and then return its value.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands show how to create a variable with a complex type and then return its properties.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands show how to create a variable with a complex type and then return its properties.

trans-unit.source: In this case, a virtual machine object from Get-AzureVM is used.
trans-unit.target: In this case, a virtual machine object from Get-AzureVM is used.

trans-unit.source: Use the Set-AutomationVariable activity to set the value of an Automation variable in a runbook and the Get-AutomationVariable to retrieve it.
trans-unit.target: Use the Set-AutomationVariable activity to set the value of an Automation variable in a runbook and the Get-AutomationVariable to retrieve it.

trans-unit.source: You shouldn't use the Set-AzureAutomationVariable or Get-AzureAutomationVariable cmdlets in a runbook since they are less efficient than the workflow activities.
trans-unit.target: You shouldn't use the Set-AzureAutomationVariable or Get-AzureAutomationVariable cmdlets in a runbook since they are less efficient than the workflow activities.

trans-unit.source: You also cannot retrieve the value of secure variables with Get-AzureAutomationVariable.
trans-unit.target: You also cannot retrieve the value of secure variables with Get-AzureAutomationVariable.

trans-unit.source: The only way to create a new variable from within a runbook is to use the <linkText>New-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The only way to create a new variable from within a runbook is to use the <linkText>New-AzureAutomationVariable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands show how to set and retrieve a variable in a textual runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands show how to set and retrieve a variable in a textual runbook.

trans-unit.source: In this sample, it is assumed that variables of type integer named NumberOfIterations and NumberOfRunnings and a variable of type string named SampleMessage have already been created.
trans-unit.target: In this sample, it is assumed that variables of type integer named NumberOfIterations and NumberOfRunnings and a variable of type string named SampleMessage have already been created.

trans-unit.source: The following sample code shows how to update a variable with a complex value in a textual runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following sample code shows how to update a variable with a complex value in a textual runbook.

trans-unit.source: In this sample, an Azure virtual machine is retrieved with Get-AzureVM and saved to an existing Automation variable.
trans-unit.target: In this sample, an Azure virtual machine is retrieved with Get-AzureVM and saved to an existing Automation variable.

trans-unit.source: As explained in <linkText>Variable types</linkText><title></title>, this is stored as a PSCustomObject.
trans-unit.target: As explained in <linkText>Variable types</linkText><title></title>, this is stored as a PSCustomObject.

trans-unit.source: In the following code, the value is retrieved from the variable and used to start the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: In the following code, the value is retrieved from the variable and used to start the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The following sample code shows how to use a variable with a collection of complex values in a textual runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following sample code shows how to use a variable with a collection of complex values in a textual runbook.

trans-unit.source: In this sample, multiple Azure virtual machines are retrieved with Get-AzureVM and saved to an existing Automation variable.
trans-unit.target: In this sample, multiple Azure virtual machines are retrieved with Get-AzureVM and saved to an existing Automation variable.

trans-unit.source: As explained in <linkText>Variable types</linkText><title></title>, this is stored as a collection of PSCustomObjects.
trans-unit.target: As explained in <linkText>Variable types</linkText><title></title>, this is stored as a collection of PSCustomObjects.

trans-unit.source: In the following code, the collection is retrieved from the variable and used to start each virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: In the following code, the collection is retrieved from the variable and used to start each virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: In a graphical runbook, you add the Get-AutomationVariable or Set-AutomationVariable by right-clicking on the variable in the Library pane of the graphical editor and selecting the activity you want.
trans-unit.target: In a graphical runbook, you add the Get-AutomationVariable or Set-AutomationVariable by right-clicking on the variable in the Library pane of the graphical editor and selecting the activity you want.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add variable to canvas</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add variable to canvas</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The following image shows sample activities to update a variable with a simple value in a graphical runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows sample activities to update a variable with a simple value in a graphical runbook.

trans-unit.source: In this sample, a single Azure virtual machine is retrieved with Get-AzureVM and the computer name is saved to an existing Automation variable with a type of String.
trans-unit.target: In this sample, a single Azure virtual machine is retrieved with Get-AzureVM and the computer name is saved to an existing Automation variable with a type of String.

trans-unit.source: It doesn't matter whether the <linkText>link is a pipeline or sequence</linkText><title></title> since we only expect a single object in the output.
trans-unit.target: It doesn't matter whether the <linkText>link is a pipeline or sequence</linkText><title></title> since we only expect a single object in the output.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set simple variable</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set simple variable</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The following image shows the activities used to update a variable with a complex value in a graphical runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows the activities used to update a variable with a complex value in a graphical runbook.

trans-unit.source: The only change from the previous example is not specifying a Field path for the Activity output on the Set-AutomationVariable activity so that the object is stored instead of just a property of the object.
trans-unit.target: The only change from the previous example is not specifying a Field path for the Activity output on the Set-AutomationVariable activity so that the object is stored instead of just a property of the object.

trans-unit.source: As explained in <linkText>Variable types</linkText><title></title>, this is stored as a PSCustomObject.
trans-unit.target: As explained in <linkText>Variable types</linkText><title></title>, this is stored as a PSCustomObject.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set complex variable</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set complex variable</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The following image shows similar functionality as the previous example, with multiple virtual machines saved to the variable.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows similar functionality as the previous example, with multiple virtual machines saved to the variable.

trans-unit.source: A sequence link must be used here so that the Set-AutomationVariable activity receives the entire set of virtual machines as one collection.
trans-unit.target: A sequence link must be used here so that the Set-AutomationVariable activity receives the entire set of virtual machines as one collection.

trans-unit.source: If a pipeline link was used, then the Set-AutomationVariable activity would run separately for each object with the result being that only the last virtual machine in the collection would be saved.
trans-unit.target: If a pipeline link was used, then the Set-AutomationVariable activity would run separately for each object with the result being that only the last virtual machine in the collection would be saved.

trans-unit.source: As explained in <linkText>Variable types</linkText><title></title>, this is stored as a collection of PSCustomObjects.
trans-unit.target: As explained in <linkText>Variable types</linkText><title></title>, this is stored as a collection of PSCustomObjects.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set complex collection variable</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set complex collection variable</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The following image shows sample activities that retrieve and use a variable in a graphical runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows sample activities that retrieve and use a variable in a graphical runbook.

trans-unit.source: The first activity retrieves the virtual machines that were saved to the variable in the previous example.
trans-unit.target: The first activity retrieves the virtual machines that were saved to the variable in the previous example.

trans-unit.source: The link needs to be a pipeline so that the Start-AzureVM activity runs once for each object sent from the Get-AutomationVariable activity.
trans-unit.target: The link needs to be a pipeline so that the Start-AzureVM activity runs once for each object sent from the Get-AutomationVariable activity.

trans-unit.source: This will work the same whether a a single object or multiple objects are stored in the variable.
trans-unit.target: This will work the same whether a a single object or multiple objects are stored in the variable.

trans-unit.source: The Start-AzureVM activity uses properties of the PSCustomObject that represents each virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The Start-AzureVM activity uses properties of the PSCustomObject that represents each virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Get complex variable</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Get complex variable</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The following image shows how to filter the objects that are stored to a variable in a graphical runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows how to filter the objects that are stored to a variable in a graphical runbook.

trans-unit.source: A <linkText>condition</linkText><title></title> is added to the link in the previous example to filter only those virtual machines that were stopped when the variable was set.
trans-unit.target: A <linkText>condition</linkText><title></title> is added to the link in the previous example to filter only those virtual machines that were stopped when the variable was set.
